description.narrative:
UNICEF and Sweden have in dialogue agreed to continue the longstanding bilateral collaboration in Mali. The contribution that this decision refers to is a support to the implementation of the last year of the Country Programme (CP) 2015-2019 as well as the first year of the new CP 2020-2024. Since the start of the current CP, important results have already been achieved, the context in Mali has changed in a significant way and new strategic direction has been provided at the global level. The CP for 2020-2024 is under development and is expected to take these changes into account. Preliminary theories of change are available for each component that Sweden will continue to finance, including information on the main changes envisaged and the stakeholders that are expected to change their attitudes, relations or behaviours. Specific targets and indicators will be further defined during the year.
Water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH)
The WASH component of the CP 2020-2024 aims to ensure that communities, families, women and children in Mali, in particular those in rural and semi-urban areas as well as those affected by humanitarian crisis, have access to sustainable drinking water and sanitation services and practices adequate hygiene and environmental behaviours. To achieve this change, UNICEF WASH focuses on two main results;
1) By 2024, the most vulnerable communities, families, women and children in rural and semi-urban areas as well as those affected by humanitarian crisis have new means and services to sustainably access drinking water and basic sanitation.
2) By 2024, schools and health centres have adequate water and sanitation infrastructure as well as improved hygiene conditions, especially the most vulnerable in rural and semi-urban areas as well as those affected by humanitarian crisis.
Child protection
The Child protection component of the CP 2020-2024 aims to ensure that children and adolescents, girls and boys, in vulnerable areas, including in humanitarian situations, are better protected against violence, exploitation and traditional practises. The Child protection component focuses on three main results;
1) By 2024, adolescents, girls and boys, benefit from an integrated and evidence-based system that protects from sexual and physical violence and exploitation and that is adapted to regional contexts and both humanitarian and development needs.
2) By 2024, adolescents, girls and boys, are equipped to protect themselves against gender-based violence, child marriage and FGM and to evolve in a social, legal and policy environment that is favourable to gender equality and autonomy of girls.
3) By 2024, all children, including those living in humanitarian contexts, receive birth certificates at birth and all children and adolescents that are victim, witness or in conflict with the law benefit from a fair, equitable and gender sensitive justice system that is adapted to contextual needs.
Social inclusion
The social inclusion component aims to ensure that all children live in a socio-economic environment that favors their ability to exercise their fundamental rights and that offers equitable chances to realize their full potential. The following three key results have been defined;
1) By 2024, the local and national state structures have sufficient technical capacity to use and analyze data on poverty in the process of elaborating public policies and during the implementation of social protection programs.
2) By 2024, the local and national actors have increased capacity to conceive, coordinate and implement integrated social protection systems and inclusive policies.
3) By 20204, the local and national actors are better equipped to raise, allocate and manage public resources that better supports children.

UNICEF och Sverige har i dialog kommit överens om att fortsätta det långvariga bilaterala samarbetet i Mali. Detta beslut hänvisar till ett stöd till genomförandet av det sista året av landprogrammet 2015–2019 samt det första året av det nya programmet 2020–2024. Det kommande landprogrammet är under utveckling och tar hänsyn till att viktiga resultat har uppnåtts de senaste fyra åren, att kontexten i Mali har förändrats på ett betydande sätt och att ny strategisk riktning har tillhandahållits på global nivå. Preliminära förändringsteorier finns tillgängliga för varje komponent som Sverige fortsätter att finansiera, inklusive information om de huvudsakliga förändringarna som planeras och de aktörer som förväntas ändra sina attityder, relationer eller beteenden. Mål och indikatorer kommer att definieras ytterligare under 2019.
Vatten, sanitet och hygien (WASH)
WASH-komponenten i landprogrammet 2020–2024 syftar till att säkerställa att samhällen, familjer, kvinnor och barn i Mali, särskilt på landsbygden och i semi-urbana områden samt dem som drabbas av humanitära kriser, har tillgång till vatten, sanitet och hygien. För att uppnå denna förändring fokuserar UNICEF WASH på två huvudresultat;
1) År 2024 har de mest utsatta samhällena, familjer, kvinnor och barn på landsbygden, i semi-urbana områden samt dem som drabbats av humanitär kris nya medel och tjänster för att säkerställa hållbar tillgång till dricksvatten och grundläggande sanitet.
2) År 2024 har skolor och vårdinstitutioner tillgång till vatten och sanitet samt förbättrade hygienförhållanden, särskilt de mest sårbara på landsbygden, i semi-urbana områden samt dem som drabbats av humanitär kris.
Skydd av barn
Barnskyddskomponenten i landprogrammet 2020–2024 syftar till att säkerställa att barn och ungdomar, flickor och pojkar, i utsatta områden, inklusive i humanitära situationer, är bättre skyddade mot våld, utnyttjande och traditionell praxis av skadlig natur. Barnskyddskomponenten fokuserar på tre huvudresultat;
1) År 2024 drar ungdomar, flickor och pojkar nytta av ett integrerat och bevisbaserat system som skyddar mot sexuellt och fysiskt våld och exploatering, anpassat till den regionala kontexten samt humanitära och utvecklingsbehov.
2) År 2024 har ungdomar, flickor och pojkar kapacitet att skydda sig mot könsbaserat våld, barnäktenskap och könsstympning samt att utvecklas i en social, juridisk och politisk miljö som är gynnsam för flickors jämställdhet och självständighet.
3) År 2024 har alla barn, inklusive de som lever i humanitära situationer, tillgång till födelsebevis vid födseln och alla barn och ungdomar som är offer, vittne eller i strid med lagen gynnas av ett rättvist och könssensitivt rättssystem som har anpassats till kontexten.
Social integration
Landprogrammets komponent som fokuserar på social integration syftar till att säkerställa att alla barn lever i en socioekonomisk miljö som gynnar deras förmåga att utöva sina grundläggande rättigheter och som ger rättvisa möjligheter att uppnå sin fulla potential. Följande tre nyckelresultat har definierats;
1) År 2024 har de lokala och nationella statliga strukturerna tillräcklig teknisk kapacitet att använda och analysera data om fattigdom för att utarbeta policy och för att genomföra sociala skyddsprogram.
2) År 2024 har de lokala och nationella aktörerna ökad kapacitet att utforma, samordna och genomföra integrerade sociala trygghetssystem och en inkluderande politik.
3) I år 2024 är de lokala och nationella aktörerna bättre rustade att öka, fördela och förvalta offentliga resurser till förmån för barn.

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.

6.a - By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.

6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling, avsaltning, vatteneffektivitet, rening av avloppsvatten, återvinning och återanvändning.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: As stated above, the contribution is towards three thematic areas i.e 1) Child Protection, 2) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene and 3) Social Policy and Inclusion. Progress achieved under each component can be assessed as satisfactory. Each thematic report provided includes both quantitative and qualitative data. Reports are result-focused and allow for an assessment at outcome and impact level. CHILD PROTECTION Key results of the Child Protection component In 2019, UNICEF put a lot of efforts to improve the data quality and its information management system to monitor results. Monitoring matrices, registration forms, follow-up tables and various other tools -, disaggregated by gender, age, handicap and areas of interventions -, were designed in collaboration with implementing partners to allow monthly monitoring of activities. UNICEF conducted regular capacity building sessions with partners to ensure the tools were adequate and user-friendly. These efforts have enabled a closer analysis and understanding of interventions. The results with respect to the one outcome level are as follows: 832 children who experienced physical, sexual or emotional violence were reached with health, psychosocial and/or legal services, both in humanitarian and development contexts. Among the children, 270 girls were victims of sexual violence, 208 (81 boys, 127 girls) were subjected to physical violence and 472 (233 boys, 239 girls) suffered from emotional violence with most of the children experiencing more than one type of violence. Birth registration and certificate delivery were improved through two strategies: strengthening interoperability between health and civil registration to register new-borns within the legal deadline; and supporting birth registration for children who had missed it through supplementary judgements in conflict-affected areas. Thanks to what has been mentioned above, 86,7% of children under 5 were registered against a target of 90%. Note, however, that the study giving this data does not take into account Northern Mali and is consequently very likely overestimated. 53.7% of Women (20-24 yrs) were married before the age 18 against a 53% target. Progress has been made towards the national strategy and costed action plan on child marriage, which is pending its adoption. 67,195 adolescent girls received prevention and care interventions to address child marriage 88.6% of women aged 15-49 have been subject to female genital mutilation Outcomes and behavioral changes within Child Protection component Based on the lessons learnt from 2018, a higher investment in data collection and analysis was made by UNICEF thanks to the flexibility of the thematic funds. UNICEF was able to produce evidence-based documents on the achievements of results and increase the attention among the international community in Mali on the criticality of child protection in emergency and mobilize media attention through the wide dissemination of the Children Under Attack campaign. In addition, the funds were used to build evidence on social norms changes, and the importance of maintaining a continuous engagement with communities. UNICEF provided technical support to the Direction Nationale de Protection de L’Enfant (Child Protection National Direction) and Agence Nationale de Communicationpour le Development (National Agency of Communication for Development) in developing an integrated communication for development strategy, action plan and communication materials/tools to address violence against children with the purpose of influencing positive attitudes and behaviours and thus to reduce violence against children at institutional, individual and community levels, as well as to progressively promote intergenerational dialogue on sexual violence and available services/resources. In an effort to better address violence against adolescents and inform programming, UNICEF started in 2019 a formative research to gather information and gain understanding on the risks and vulnerabilities of adolescents, boys and girls, in six different areas in Mali (Bamako, Kayes, Sikasso, Segou, Gao, Mopti, Kenieba) with the aim to develop, in 2020, a gender transformative, cultural and psychosocial support methodology appropriate to the context in order to empower adolescents and youths. The formative research also examines dynamics and practices around gender norms, coping mechanisms, sexual abuse and exploitation in these areas. Results will be available in 2020. Thematic funds have been also used to build evidence on social norms changes, and the importance of maintaining a continuous engagement with communities. Approaches used included also age and gender sensitive focus-group and intergenerational dialogues, community theater, and public debates to facilitate discussion about girls' and women's health issues as en entry point to tackling child marriage, Female Genital Mutilation (FGM), and gender norms. Among these sensitized persons, 135,377 persons, out of the 205,000 targeted, regularly participated in dialogs promoting gender equitable norms including delaying child marriage. Activities undetaken in child friendly spaces including group discussions, literacy, dancing and information sessions on children's rights, enabled children to return to their daily routine and overcome trauma. WASH Key results of the WASH component The WASH team within UNICEF has achieved important results between 2015-2019 although the progress towards the SDGs will be very challenging to reach. The results with respect to the two outcome level indicators are as follows (note that the most recent data is from 2017): The percentage of population with access to an improved drinking water source has increased from 74 to 78% between 2015 to 2019 compared to the target of 82% (JMP, 2017) The percentage of population practicing open defecation has decreased from 8 to 7% between 2015 to 2019 compared to the target of 5% (JMP, 2017) UNICEF were close to meeting or exceeded output targets with respect to providing humanitarian WASH services (701,026 people supported with respect to the target of 500,000), installing WASH facilities in schools (1,128 schools supported compared to the target of 1,180) and ensuring minimum standard of WASH facilities in health centers (in 456 health centers compared to the target of 420). UNICEF also made important progress with respect to supporting key systems that are important to follow up and promote sustainability; the SIGMA database which provides an atlas of water supply works, a national post ODF monitoring system within the scope of rolling out of the national strategy and the Trackfin initiative which follows financial flows within the sector. During 2019, WASH funding was mainly directed towards humanitarian needs and prioritized water over hygiene and sanitation. The number of people accessing a sustainable drinking water service as a result of UNICEF direct support between 2015-2019 was 200,000 people compared to the target of 300,000 and baseline of 186,800. The number of communities certified free of open defecation as a result of UNICEF direct support between 2015-2019 was 1,319 compared to the target of 1,500 and baseline of 1,264. Outcomes and behavioral changes within WASH The outputs above are part of a strategic approach where UNICEF focuses on integrating nutrition in WASH practices to achieve improved health status of the population and a close collaboration with the education actors to promote better schooling. UNICEF has, in collaboration with Wateraid, specifically focused on promoting menstrual hygiene management (MHM) and on understanding social norms, taboo and barriers to menstrual hygiene to better adapt the program. In addition, the sustainability compact focuses on changing behaviors to focus less on the infrastructure and more on the social aspects around management and other aspects that are important to ensure sufficient maintenance. SOCIAL POLICY AND INCLUSION Key results of the Social Policy and Inclusion component The main achievements in 2019 are: Concerning the mainstreaming of child in Government policies and national plans, in 2019, the Government of Mali finalized its economic recovery and sustainable development document (CREDD 2019-2023). For the first time, it includes data on the monetary and multidimensional poverty of children, which will inform social protection interventions for children. With the support of the Social Protection Technical and Financial Partners Working Group, led by UNICEF, the Government is evaluating its 2016-2018 social protection action plan and developing the new 2020-2024 plan. This new plan will consider the elements of a social protection floor for Mali. To strengthen the coordination of social protection interventions, the Government officially launched the Unified Social Register (RSU) at the end of November 2019. This register (database) will contain information from all social protection, contributory and non-contributory programmes, with potential and actual beneficiaries. The number of new children identified in the poorest households for free health care under the Medical Assistance Programme (RAMED) has almost doubled, from 17,404 in 2018 to 39,323 in 2019. This progress was achieved through mobile/electronic collection of information in Kayes, Sikasso and Mopti regions, with UNICEF support, representing 82.7 per cent of the new registrations in 2019. Social protection for vulnerable families was strengthened in 2018 and 2019. At the end of 2018, 79,168 households representing 459,174 children benefited from the national social safety net programme ‘’Jigisemejiri’’, the largest and most critical social safety net programme, representing an increase of 16.6 per cent and 65,545 additional children versus 2017. Data is not yet available for 2019. UNICEF's support focused mainly on building the capacity of government staffs through their participation in high-level international meetings. UNICEF also supported the analysis of the evolution of the poverty index of the communes (IPC), participated in the social protection coordination mechanisms, and produced a public budget analysis for nutrition to support the National Nutrition Forum. Outcomes and behavioral changes within Social Policy and Inclusion component Behavioral changes in the component Social Policy and Inclusion as well as in those of Child Protection is a long-term process. For instance, while national technical capacity has been strengthened to conduct analyses on child multi-dimensional poverty, the Government is not equipped yet to include child-sensitive budgeting in their planning. UNICEF has advocated with and supported the Government to increase national resources allocated to social sectors and will pursue relevant partnerships with international and local actors. To ensure proper implementation of policies and programmes, social protection coordination structures must be functional at all levels. The involvement and participation of communities must be effective. Weak information systems have reduced the ability to adequately monitor and evaluate policies, programmes and interventions. To ensure a better coordination of social protection programmes in Mali, it will be crucial to accelerate the implementation of the Unified Social Register (RSU), launched in November 2019, by including age and sex-disaggregated data on more beneficiaries and more social protection programmes (beyond the two currently covered), such as school feeding programmes or farming inputs programmes. The use of new technologies in data collection significantly reduced the required time to re-read, track and ensure not only consistency of the data collected, but also good quality, reliability and security (GPS coordinates, images, sound interviews, signatures, etc...)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
